bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, May 13, 1921

div1.p: Carter recommends Walcott for yellow fever work, although he is inexperienced in mosquito control.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, May 13, 1921
div1.opener:
Address
Dr. Allan Walcott,
% Northern Aluminium Co., Ltd.
31 Budge Row,
London, E. C.
England.
I. H. B.
/LC
2121 California St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 13, 1921.
Walcott
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I am enclosing the address of Dr. Allan Walcott. He is proba-
bly available, but not immediately available. I presume he could
reach Peru within a month or six weeks if cabled for.

In my judgement, he was excellent material and his experience
since he left the Isthmus should have been good training for the
class of work to be done. He has had little, if any, systematic
experience in Stegomyia control: Converse, of course, has, but
I judge is unavailable. He, Walcott, is unmarried and extremely
energetic and careless of his own comfort--tough under tropical
conditions of living. I have, to an extent, kept in touch with
him, having seen him several--three--times since he left the
Zone, the last time in the fall of 1918.

He might not get to Peru in time to be of very much service
and then again he might. If he developes, as I think he would, he
would be a good man to have on your roster independently of the
immediate need. I think it would be well to get him for Peru & future
,

Beverly is a Major in the Medical Corps of the Army--at Langley
Field (near Fort Monroe) Va., and is, of course, unavailable.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. Enclosure.
